results.title: The Good Fight
results.creator_credit: Beck Cole, Citt Williams and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
The good fight is a documentary film about masculinity in a modern world, spirituality and the lore of the boxing ring. Set in Dulwich Hill, Sydney’s inner west, the film delves into the gritty existence of a local ‘Fight Club’ led by an unlikely character, Rev. Dave Smith. The story evolves around Rev. Dave’s relationships with the young people who frequent the Fight Club. Includes interviews with Jared Tekaki, Craig (Shorty) Sutton, Shaun Joyce and Alex Tui.
Contains some b&w images.

results.title: Grace
results.creator_credit: Damien Power, Isabel Perez, AFTRS and Alice Addison
results.brief_description:
A lonely girl left looking after the family motel finds her life is about to change when a sophisticated and elegant woman books in for the night.
Cast: Mariel McClovey, Angela Punch McGregor, Tim Richards

results.title: 3 things
results.brief_description: This humourous very short experimental film has a twist to it - it has three everyday things that will make you take a second look. Fun, quirky, different.

results.title: Backthenrightnowlateron
results.creator_credit: David Megarrity, Luke Monsour and Queensland Performing Arts Centre
results.brief_description:
Mixing interviews, images and tiny fictions, “Backthenrightnowlateron” is a funny and moving collection of children’s thoughts on their past, present and future.
The work is divided into three segments - Backthen, Rightnow, Lateron. Each segment features children from Class 2J, Yeronga State School, with their favourite toy sharing their thoughts with interviewer Georgia Seffrin, and a mini-film starring one of the toys - Chicky goes to nana’s house, Red Ted goes to England, Minotaur goes to war. Provides a wonderful and amusing insight into young children’s minds.
Developed from an original concept and commission by QPAC’s “Out of the Box” Festival of Early Childhood for the OOTB Symposium, September 2003.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Megarrity, Luke Monsour and Queensland Performing Arts Centre

results.title: Selected works from "Bute utes: the movie"
results.brief_description:
A selection of 9 narrative works from across regional Victoria by various storytellers.
Produced by Regional Arts Victoria, ACE Connections, East Gippsland Aboriginal Arts Corporation, Robinvale Cultural Festival and Network House, The South-West Institute of TAFE and the Tarerer Gunditj Association and supported by The Regional Arts Fund, The Myer Foundation and VicHealth.

results.title: FAWN
results.credit_line: Commissioned by ACMI as part of a larger project commissioned by RISING
results.brief_description:
FAWN connects characters from popular culture with everyday people who have the lived experience of losing a parent. Dressed in a kind of orphan drag and performing acts of care on each other, they form temporary bonds and act out unlikely intimacies. FAWN queers the notion of family and acknowledges that loss doesn’t always lead to a heroic coming of age adventure.

This work was commissioned by ACMI as part of a larger project commissioned by RISING.

results.title: The Long Now
results.brief_description: There is a giant clock ringing deep inside a mountain in the belly of the Sierra Diablo Ranges - The land of the Devil. It is a huge clock, hundreds of feet tall, designed to tick for 10,000 years. The mountain in which the clock resides is privately owned by Jeff Bezos. Programmed never to chime the same melody twice, its anyone’s guess how many beautiful songs will never be heard over the clock’s 10 millennial lifespan. Xanthe Dobbie’s new experimental desktop performance ponders the human urge to seek immortality. Featuring original epic hero Gilgamesh and the disembodied deep fake voice of Alan Rickman, The Long Now collapses histories, illuminating ancient and contemporary myth-making practices.

results.title: HYPER//ECHO
results.creator_credit: Andrew Gleeson, Cecile Richard and Firepit Collective
results.brief_description: HYPER//ECHO points to our relationship with technology and the digital world, how brittle and ephemeral – often by design – its infrastructure really is, and to the fundamental human desire to preserve and pass down knowledge, even when buildings crumble down, languages wane, and hyperlinks break.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Andrew Gleeson, Cecile Richard and Firepit Collective
results.description: HYPER/ECHO points to our relationship with technology and the digital world, how brittle and ephemeral – often by design – its infrastructure really is, and to the fundamental human desire to preserve and pass down knowledge, even when buildings crumble down, languages wane, and hyperlinks break.

results.title: Gaps
results.credit_line: Co-commissioned by ACMI and Carriageworks (Sydney). The co-commission of ‘Gaps’ by ACMI and Carriageworks has been assisted by the Australian Government through the Australian Council for the Arts.
results.brief_description:
One of Australia’s finest video artists, Rosetzky’s captivating works have been exhibited widely throughout Australia and internationally. ‘Gaps’ embodies Rosetzky’s ongoing exploration of personal identity and the relationship - or ‘gaps’ - between self and other through speech, movement and dance.

Rosetzky’s collaborators on ‘Gaps’ include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed ‘How to Feel’ 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.

Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.

The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period. Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.
results.description:

Gaps embodies Rosetzky’s ongoing exploration of personal identity and the relationship – or ‘gaps’ – between self and other through speech, movement and dance.

Rosetzky’s collaborators on Gaps include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed How to Feel, 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.

Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.

The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period.

Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.

Rosetzky’s collaborators on Gaps include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed How to Feel, 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.

Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.

The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period.

Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.
results.credit_line_for_label: Co-commissioned by ACMI and Carriageworks (Sydney). The co-commission of ‘Gaps’ by ACMI and Carriageworks has been assisted by the Australian Government through the Australian Council for the Arts.

details.label: Measurements
display_values:
Duration: 35 mins, 7 seconds
The work does not need to be seen from beginning to end, viewers are invited to approach and engage with the work at any point throughout the duration.

production_dates.notes:
Co-commissioned by ACMI and Carriageworks (Sydney).
David Rosetzky: Gaps will be a free exhibition at ACMI from 5 August 2014 to 8 February 2015.
The co-commission of Gaps by ACMI and Carriageworks has been assisted by the Australian Government through the Australian Council for the Arts, its arts funding and advisory body.
